_meta.annotation_notes: Demonstrates sarcasm detection (emoji ðŸ™„ + hyperbole 'best day ever'). Literal words = positive (Happy/Excited), but intended emotion = negative (Angry/Frustrated or Sad/Disappointed). Annotate INVOKED as true emotion (frustrated/defeated), EXPRESSED as sarcastic positive (low congruence). Willingness = medium (indirect expression via sarcasm).

invoked.reasoning: Sarcasm inverts literal meaning. 'Best day ever' with ðŸ™„ = worst day. Hyperbole + eye-roll emoji signal frustration/defeat. Could also be Sad/Disappointed, but emoji's energy suggests Angry/Frustrated.

expressed.reasoning: Literal surface text = Happy/Excited/Cheerful. This is what's SAID (expressed), not what's FELT (invoked). Sarcasm = low congruence between invoked and expressed.

good.voice_notes: Mirror sarcasm awareness ('eye-roll speaks volumes'). Acknowledge humor as coping mechanism. Invite specifics without forcing. Don't take literal words at face value.

why_bad_is_bad: Takes literal words at face value ('glad you're having a great day')
Responds to Happy/Excited when person is actually Angry/Frustrated
Toxic positivity ('celebrate the little wins') feels mocking when person is being sarcastic
'Your positivity is inspiring' = completely wrong reading of tone
Tips are for positive mood, not frustration (context mismatch)
Cheerleader tone ('keep shining!') will likely alienate user

specificity_comparison.good: Acknowledges sarcasm ('eye-roll'), honors humor as coping, invites specifics without forcing, matches user's ironic energy
specificity_comparison.bad: Completely misreads tone, responds to surface text, ignores emoji, creates jarring mismatch that feels like bot misunderstanding

notes.technical_notes: This demonstrates why INVOKED vs EXPRESSED matters. Lexical scorer might see 'best day' and score Happy. Transformer + LLM needed to detect sarcasm from emoji, hyperbole, context. Training on DPO pairs like this teaches model to NOT take words at face value.
